Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 43125  
Regional–Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
December 2010 
 
 
 
Improving Public Management to Achieve Better 
Development Results in Central and West Asia  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CWFM  –  Financial Sector, Public Management and Trade Division, 
Central and West Asia Department 
  PFM  –  public financial management 
  PPP  –  public–private partnership

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The global financial crisis revealed the fiscal vulnerability of the Central and West Asian 
countries1 to external shocks. Some countries requested crisis recovery and countercyclical 
support programs to tide them over during the tight fiscal situation in 2009 and to cover critical 
expenditures, particularly in the social sectors and safety nets. Fiscal resources are still limited, 
yet  essential  public  goods  and  services  must  be  delivered.  Included  here  are  goods  and 
services in core sectors under the long-term strategy framework of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) for 2009–2020 (Strategy 2020), such as education, energy, transport, and water supply 
and sanitation.2 The governments must see to it that service delivery improves and public 
investments  become  more  efficient  because  of  governance,  public  financial  management 
(PFM), and related interventions. Moreover, policy lending should not only help create enabling 
environments for sector investments but also leverage reforms to promote investments. 
 
2.  The technical assistance (TA) aims to help the institutions in Central and West Asia 
manage (i.e., plan, allocate, monitor, and account for) public resources in an optimal manner to 
achieve  more  targeted  and  effective  results  in  education  and  water  supply  and  sanitation 
sectors. It will also amplify the impact and outcome of ADB’s public management operations in 
Central  and  West  Asia.  Rapid  gap  assessments  in  core  sectors  will  first  identify  public 
management  interventions  that  can  improve  the  results  of  investment  projects.  Results 
management  and  governance  tool  kits  customized  to  suit  each  country’s  needs  will  be 
developed  for  each  sector.  Pilots  will  then  be  designed  for  programmatic  lending  to  help 
participating countries achieve more targeted policy reform as well as effective and tangible 
results in core sectors in line  with ADB’s results framework.  It will likewise benefit ADB’s 
engagement with participating countries. The TA will also provide advisory support and training, 
at  the  sector  level,  in  budget  planning  and  execution,  procurement,  fiduciary  control,  and 
financing options. The Central and West Asian countries have been made aware by the global 
financial crisis of the risks of inertia in critical governance and public management reforms, and 
should  mostly  own  and  support  the  reforms  under  the  TA.3  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Weak links between public management operations and sector activities. Through 
policy-based lending, ADB has been engaged in improving public resource management in the 
Central and West Asian countries, specifically Afghanistan and Pakistan (mainly Balochistan, 
Punjab, and Sindh provinces). Since 2003, more than $1 billion has been provided to leverage 
public management reforms. Most of the reforms involved revenue generation, budgeting, the 
private provision of public goods, and the strengthening of the civil service. While most of the 
reforms had some positive impact on country systems, a more tangible and clearer link to 
improvements in policy and results management areas has been hard to establish. A major 
factor is the absence of more in-depth sector-specific interventions in favor of general process 
policy reforms that will have cross cutting impact. Central and West Asian countries continue to 
face capacity constraints that prevent maximizing synergies between policy-based operations

2   
and investment projects in core sectors, which could translate to more tangible results.4 ADB’s 
public management operations should have greater sector impact and reforms should improve 
operating environments in the core sectors supported under Strategy 2020. 
 
4.  Unquantifiable results of policy lending. The results of public resource management 
reform programs have been difficult to quantify. Support has generally been provided through 
program lending: fund disbursements are quick and transaction costs low. However, the links 
between policy alternatives and outcomes are often unclear. Many programs are too ambitious 
and complex, and well beyond the capacity of government to implement them. Multitranche 
programs lock the parties into anticipated future states, then shifts in policy priorities undo their 
assumptions. Cluster programs are more flexible, but they require a clear medium-term reform 
agenda,  which  is  often  based  on  input.  If  this  reform  agenda  is  not  realized,  program 
disbursement––if it occurs at all––becomes complicated and is delayed. In contrast, project 
lending, while providing a clear link between financing and outcomes, is frequently rigid in 
preparation, and the conservative project designs that result often limit the space for midcourse 
corrections.  Project  financing  frequently  involves  high  transaction  costs  linked  to 
implementation, delays due to capacity constraints in the borrowing country, and donor process 
requirements—all of which often stand in the way of results. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
5.  The  expected  impact  of the TA  is  more  efficient  and  effective  public  services  and 
infrastructure in education and water supply and sanitation, as measured by improvements in 
the level 2 indicators in the ADB results framework for the Central and West Asian countries. 
Among these indicators are classrooms built and upgraded, teachers trained, water supply 
pipes installed or upgraded, new households connected to water supply, wastewater treated, 
and households served with new sanitation connections. 
 
6.  The expected outcome is improved results orientation in participating Central and West 
Asian countries in the core sectors under Strategy 2020, particularly in education and in water 
supply and sanitation. During TA implementation, results-based public management operations 
will be prepared in the participating Central and West Asian countries.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The TA will have four outputs: (i) rapid assessment of country sectoral governance and 
PFM, and the related capacity-building needs; (ii) sector results management and governance 
tool  kits;  (iii) the  design  of  pilots  for  results-  and  risk-based  programmatic  lending;  and 
(iv) training, workshops, and conference. 
1.  Rapid Assessment of Country Sectoral Governance and Public Financial 
Management, and the Related Capacity-Building Needs  
8.  The TA will support rapid assessments of governance and PFM needs, and the related 
gaps, in education, energy, transport, and water supply and sanitation. The work will build on 
the country and sector risk assessments under the Second Governance and Anticorruption 
                                                
4  E.g., policy reforms to increase transparency and accountability, provide financing options, overcome obstacles 
including procurement problems, make government fund flows more efficient, improve sector governance, and 
develop an environment conducive to more effective and efficient investment projects.

3 
Action Plan (GACAP II).5 A desk review will be made, followed by fieldwork in selected Central 
and West Asian countries. The stocktaking exercise will  examine sector needs relating to 
budget  execution,  procurement,  fiduciary  control,  the  impact  of  regulations  on  investment 
projects, and institutional arrangements. It will also look into the need in specific countries for 
efficiency-improving innovations (such as e-governance), alternative methods of financing (such 
as public–private partnership [PPP]), intergovernmental fiscal transfers, and complaint redress 
mechanisms. How sector performance objectives and indicators align with country goals and 
targets  will  be  analyzed.  The  assessment  will  cover  as  well  the  adequacy  of  country 
management information systems to provide timely and accurate data for measuring results. 
Assessments already made under the Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA) 
Program6 will be considered, and PEFA indicators included and updated, where applicable. The 
government and other stakeholders will be consulted, as will ADB, to maximize synergies 
between governance and sector specialists. (See the supplementary appendix for a discussion 
of governance and PFM risks.) 
2.  Sector Results Management and Governance Tool Kits 
9.  In parallel with the rapid gap assessments, sector results management and governance 
tool kits will be prepared for the use by (i) government staff in participating countries (mainly 
finance, planning, and line [sector] ministries); (ii) project implementation units; and (iii) ADB 
staff.  The  tool  kits  will  help  to  create  governance  environments  that  can  yield  timely, 
cost-effective, and tangible results. They will also assist participating countries in policy dialogue 
to  facilitate  the  design  and  implementation  of  improved  policy  lending  and  investment 
operations. The tool kits will be developed by experts in managing for development results 
(MfDR) and in governance, pilot-tested in education and water supply and sanitation, and 
customized to fit the countries’ needs. Ongoing and previous work in MfDR will be considered in 
the design of the tool kits. The tool kits are envisaged to provide guidance in the following areas, 
among others: 
(i)  the operating environment in  each sector, including the legal and regulatory 
framework,7  the  procurement  framework,  institutional  and  oversight 
arrangements, and state subsidies and transfers; 
(ii)  best practice financial and funds flow arrangements for sector investments; 
(iii)  best practice procurement systems; 
(iv)  monitoring and reporting options; 
(v)  method of assessing the impact of regulations on investment projects; 
(vi)  best practice corporate governance structures;  
(vii)  sectoral performance indicators including (a) a suggested list of sector indicators 
consistent  with  country  goals  and  targets,  and  (b)  available  international 
benchmarks and indicators from comparator countries; 
(viii)  best practices in management information systems for measuring results;  
(ix)  best practices in tariff pricing, where applicable; and 
(x)  best practices in public accountability mechanisms. 
3.  Proposals  to  Pilot  Results-  and  Risk-Based  Programmatic  Lending 
Designed 
10.  Building on output (i) and (ii) (para. 7), the TA consultants will design proposals to pilot 
results- and risk-based programmatic (policy) lending that strengthens the link between policy

4   
reforms and sector investments. The proposals to pilot results- and risk-based lending will assist 
the  participating  countries  to  better  support  a  results  management  culture  generally  and 
programmatic engagements with development partners in particular. This will be framed within 
existing policies of ADB and will allow the participating countries and ADB to focus on the 
soundness and technical quality of the program, the pattern of expenditures and the quality of 
the system within which the expenditure takes place, and the monitoring and verification of 
results. 
 
11.   The TA will also design  proposals for developing  model structures of results- and 
risk-based programmatic lending for ADB interventions in education and water supply and 
sanitation.  A  results-oriented  lending  pipeline  linked  to  country  development  and  key 
performance  indicators for  participating  countries  can  thus  be  developed.  If resources  are 
available, similar modes of lending may also be designed for transport and energy. The Central 
and West Asian countries will be consulted on the possible pilot-testing of this lending mode. 
For countries that request ADB programmatic support in implementing reforms, ADB will work 
with policy makers, development partners, and other stakeholders to help identify and develop a 
pipeline of future results-oriented lending programs. This new approach will better integrate 
reforms in public resource management components of sector reforms with investments in the 
sector.  The  Strategy  and  Policy  Department  (SPD)  of  ADB  will  be  closely  consulted  in 
developing this component. 
 
12.  Consultants will be mobilized to provide advisory and technical support to policy makers 
and  stakeholders  in  specific  reform  areas  and  innovative  approaches  to  (i) ensure  proper 
internal  controls;  (ii) reduce  the  regulatory  burden;  (iii) improve  procurement  efficiency; 
(iv) increase the efficiency of intergovernmental fiscal transfers to support local government 
delivery of social services like education; (v) identify financing options for public services and 
investments,  e.g.,  through  PPP;  (vi) identify  opportunities  for  e-governance  activities;  and 
(vii) develop more effective and responsive mechanisms for handling complaints. Case studies 
on results- and risk-based policy lending products will also be prepared. 
 
13.   As  part  of  the  design  of  results-  and  risk-based  lending,  a  list  of  disaggregated 
indicators  will  be  developed  for  various  sectors,  to  be  used  in  tracking  and  reporting  the 
contribution of ADB financing and its value addition. The indicators will be in addition to the 
policy conditions and will serve as interim signposts for tracking progress in service delivery and 
other  areas. (See  Appendix  2  for  a  more  detailed  presentation  of  results-  and  risk-based 
programmatic lending) 
4.  Training, Workshops, and Conference  
14.  Training needs in governance, PFM, and MfDR will be identified and a training program 
developed  for  financing  under  the  TA.  Peer-to-peer  learning,  as  well  as  capacity-building 
approaches that promote links with other governments implementing related reforms in the 
region, will be supported. The training programs will be aimed at improving public service 
delivery. They will also broaden stakeholder awareness of results management, and the design 
and implementation of the pilot results- and risk-based programmatic lending. Staff of relevant 
partner  agencies  will  be  trained.  Knowledge  sharing  will  take  place  through  a  regional 
conference organized to improve the impact of public management operations on education and 
related knowledge products. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed 
with  a  grant  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–other  sources).  The

5 
financing  will  cover  the  remuneration  and  travel  expenses  of  international  and  national 
consultants; workshop, training, and conference expenses; the cost of the rapid assessments 
and  tool  kits;  reports  and  communications;  and  other  miscellaneous  expenses.  The  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. During TA implementation, ADB will explore 
possible cofinancing from other development partners to augment funding for TA activities. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency, and the Financial Sector, Public Management and 
Trade Division, Central and West Asia Department (CWFM), the implementing agency.8 CWFM 
will closely monitor the implementation and evaluate the achievements of the TA through the 
design and monitoring framework. CWFM will also work closely with other sector divisions, and 
ADB’s Office of the General Counsel (OGC), Private Sector Operations Department, and SPD 
to ensure complementarity in projects. The TA is expected to begin in January 2011, and be 
completed by June 2013. Financial closing of the TA is expected by December 2013.  
 
17.  ADB input will total 29 person-months of international and 18 person-months of national 
consulting services. To help implement output (i)–(iii) (para. 7), a firm will be hired through 
quality- and cost-based selection using a simplified technical proposal and 80:20 weighting to 
provide  25 person-months  of  international  and  14  person-months  of  national  consulting 
services. The consultants will (i) undertake the rapid gap assessments of governance and PFM, 
(ii) prepare the results management and governance tool kit, and (iii) provide advisory and 
technical support in the design the pilots for results- and risk-based programmatic lending. The 
consultants hired for output (i)–(iii) will also provide input as experts for the training program and 
workshops. 
 
18.  Individual  consultants  will  be  hired  for  output (iv)  (para. 7)  to  (i) prepare  training, 
workshop, and regional conference materials; and (ii) organize, coordinate, and conduct the 
training  program,  workshops,  and  conference.  Up  to  four  experts  will  be  hired  for 
4 person-months each of international and national consulting services. National consulting 
services  will  include  administrative  support  for  the  training  program,  workshops,  and 
conference. Resource persons for the regional conference will also be hired for output (iv).  
 
19.  Appendix 4 discusses the outline terms of references for the consultants. ADB will hire 
the consultants according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time  to  time).  To  avoid  delay,  the  hiring  will  be  done  through  advance  contracting,  in 
consultation with ADB’s Central Operations Services Office. The TA disbursement will conform 
to ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
20.  Good practices and lessons will be  spread through policy dialogue and knowledge 
sharing, including the publication of knowledge products. Performance and outcomes will be 
evaluated at the end of the TA and published in a TA completion report.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for Improving Public Management to Achieve Better Development Results in Central and West 
Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 2 
PROPOSALS TO PILOT RESULTS- AND RISK-BASED PROGRAMMATIC LENDING 
1.  Proposals to pilot results- and risk-based programmatic lending can potentially improve 
on  some  of  the  problems  of  project  and  program  lending  by  assessing  and  designing 
development interventions on the basis of the risks posed to aid effectiveness as reflected in the 
intended  results. The  proposals for  a  results-  and  risk-based  lending  design  factor  in  the 
quantum  of  risk  posed  by  a  particular  programmatic  intervention  and  the  implementation 
environment and can assist to enhance the intensity and quality of dialogue between the 
development partner and the recipient country, leading to a consensual approach to reforms. 
The proposals can cover support for a medium-term ―government-owned‖ sector or subsector 
reform program with sector or subsector results which can extend to  areas of policy and 
institutional reforms as well as service delivery outcomes. The proposals for this new design will 
seek to link measurable expenditure benchmarks, outcome, and outputs. These indicators can 
be separate and distinct from the sector results usually contained in a policy matrix. 
 
2.  One potential model of the pilot results- and risk-based programmatic lending can have 
a development partner finance all or part of the financing gap in the implementation plan.  
Assistance can be released in tranches linked to performance targets in an agreed results 
matrix with possible additional linkages to supplementary targets such as attainment of the 
expenditure  targets  in  identified  eligible  expenditure  areas.  Another  variation  can  seek  to 
strengthen results  linkages further  by  equally  apportioning  the  tranche  amount  among the 
agreed results areas, and making the release contingent on meeting targets in a specified 
minimum percentage of results areas. A more sophisticated version of the pilot can create 
separability of intra-tranche funding lines and allow the withholding of a portion of the tranche for 
the unmet results, and its rollover to the next tranche cycle. While affording a closer link to the 
results, these options for a piloting of results- and risk-based programmatic lending can act as a 
powerful horizontal balancer, ensuring equal attention to each of the agreed reform areas.1  
 
3.  The proposals to pilot results- and risk-based program lending will also comment on the 
issues  linked  to  the  use  of  the  recipient  government’s  systems  rather  than  the  donor’s 
guidelines in dispensing aid funds. Other areas that would be covered include greater reliance 
on country systems that may not be fully mature in terms of public financial management (PFM), 
procurement, anticorruption systems, and other issues such as ability to track expenditure. The 
proposals  will  also  look  at  the  need  to  analyze  the  risks  in  sector  systems  as  well  as 
government’s  commitment  to  reforms.  The  wider  policy  and  governance  environment  also 
needs to be studied and a risk management plan commensurate with the extent and quantum of 
risks faced in each of the above areas put in place. Where it may not be possible to reasonably 
mitigate  all  risks,  one  option  is  to  develop  special  fiduciary  arrangements  (e.g.,  special 
accounts, expenditure tracking, regular audits) and very clear links to indicators (to ensure that 
the programmatic part remains on track). The other option may be to continue ring-fencing 
development assistance through the project mode of finance. A low-risk environment would be 
more suitable to the pilot results- and risk-based programmatic lending. Depending on the 
strength of the PFM environment, the processing time may also be shortened in low-risk sectors 
and countries. 
 
4.  The proposals to pilot results- and risk-based programmatic financing must focus of key 
systemic requirements such as a reliable system of monitoring and evaluation to track the 
performance of both the sector objectives and the program output and outcomes. A natural

accompaniment of such an approach is a relative shift in focus from the preparation and design 
of the lending instrument to the program supervision and implementation support that will help 
strengthen processes and controls according to the risks identified. Thus, typically the program 
implementation unit is assisted through resident experts and specialists, who help to develop 
capacity within the government ministries to deal with the procurement, expenditure tracking, 
and results monitoring functions.  
 
5.  The proposals to pilot a results- and risk-based lending instrument may therefore work to 
support  a  programmatic  engagement,  where  a  development  partner  finances  output  and 
outcomes in a sound planning and fiduciary environment without the need for direct accounting 
links between resource disbursement and expenditures by the recipient country. The reliance on 
the  recipient  country’s  accounting  and  reporting  system,  supported  by  performance  and 
financial audit, allows the development partner to concentrate on the soundness and technical 
quality of the program, the pattern of expenditures and the quality of the system within which the 
expenditures takes place, and the monitoring and verification of results achieved.2

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Public Finance Specialist and Team Leader (8 person-months, international) 
1.  As team leader, the consultant will have the following responsibilities: 
(i)  develop  a  technical  assistance  (TA)  implementation  plan,  and  assist  in  the  further 
development of the other consultants’ terms of reference and in their recruitment;  
(ii)  agree on the individual consultants’ work plans with the project officer from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB);  
(iii)  coordinate with ADB country offices and with government counterparts to facilitate the 
individual consultants’ engagements and expected outcomes;  
(iv)  assist the individual consultants, particularly in rapid gap assessments; 
(v)  review the consultants’ output and reports for quality assurance;  
(vi)  coordinate with the training coordinator on the training program, workshops, and regional 
conference; and 
(vii)  advise ADB on the quality and timeliness of the individual consultants’ output. 
 
2.  As public finance specialist, the consultant will have the following responsibilities: 
(i)  organize rapid gap assessments in public financial management (PFM) in the central 
(ministries  of  finance,  planning,  economy  and  similar  agencies)  and  social  sector 
ministries,  particularly  in  the  following  areas:  (a)  budget  planning,  in  terms  of 
coordination with sector planning, and the quality of consultation between the central 
and sector ministries; (b) budget execution, in terms of the predictability of fund releases 
to the sector ministries as budgeted, cash planning and management, commitment 
control  and  procurement  authority,  and  capacity  of  the  sector  ministries  for  timely, 
efficient, and transparent procurement; and (c) soundness of accounting and reporting, 
existence and operability of fiduciary controls, and their appropriateness and adequacy 
for identifying likely conflicts of interest and  averting wrongful procurement (internal 
control) or uncovering any misuse of funds (external audit) and holding the offenders to 
account through executive follow-up and legislative oversight;  
(ii)  analyze  the  legal  basis,  institutional  layout,  implementation  capacity,  and  prevailing 
sector practice in the above operating areas; 
(iii)  comparing the findings with international good practice, identify the gaps in institutions, 
structures, systems, procedures, and capacities, and suggest remedies;  
(iv)  provide technical advice on issues related to intergovernmental fiscal transfers and other 
governance risks; and 
(v)  design and assist in implementing a training program and workshops in PFM.  
 
3.  The consultant must have a master’s degree in finance, economics, or other relevant 
social science with 10 years’ relevant professional experience or equivalent combination of 
education and experience working with ADB or other international development partners in 
governance, PFM, and development areas. A good working knowledge of public resource 
management in Central and West Asia would be an advantage. 
B.  Public Management Specialist (3 person-months, international) 
4.  The consultant will prepare a work plan for rapid governance gap assessments in the 
selected  sectors,  particularly  education  and  water  supply  and  sanitation,  in  the  identified 
countries in Central and West Asia. 
 
5.  For each such undertaking, the consultant will  
(i)  review  the  relevant  literature,  interact  with  government  counterparts  and  run  focus 
groups discussions to understand issues, and determine the options for remedying the 
problems;

12  Appendix 4 
 
(ii)  in gap assessment exercises, analyze the following areas in particular: (a) the sector 
planning framework, for consistency with sector goals and objectives, programmatic or 
medium-term orientation, and focus on results; (b) sector governance and horizontal and 
vertical assignment of responsibilities, including the extent of delegation to the local 
governments for service delivery; (c) the quality and adequacy of human resources and 
appropriateness  of  incentives;  and  (d)  the  accountability  structure  and  performance 
measurement arrangements;  
(iii)  analyze the legal basis, institutional layout, implementation capacities, and prevailing 
sector practice in the above operating areas;  
(iv)  comparing the findings with international good practice, identify the gaps in institutions, 
structures, systems, procedures, and capacities; 
(v)  identify areas of intervention for ADB, and assist in identification of a future pipeline of 
projects and programs; and 
(vi)  act as resource person in the training program and workshops. 
 
6.  The consultant must have at least a bachelor’s degree (a master’s degree is preferable) 
in economics, development studies, or other relevant social science with at least 5 years’ work 
with the public sector and ADB or other international development partners in governance, PFM, 
and development areas. A good working knowledge of public resource management in Central 
and West Asia would be highly valued. 
C.  Experts in Managing for Development Results (3 person-months, international) 
7.  The  consultants  will  prepare  a  work  plan  for  developing  a  results  management 
framework and allied tool kits for the selected sectors, particularly education and water supply 
and sanitation, in the identified Central and West Asian countries. 
 
8.  For each such undertaking, the consultants will 
(i)  study the sector development strategy and facilitate, through a participative process, the 
development of the results chain from strategic objectives to intermediate and immediate 
outcomes and output to final outcomes; 
(ii)  help identify the linkages between the results chain and resource requirements, both 
material and human, including the locus of results ownership, and responsibility for the 
provision of resources and the achievement of results;  
(iii)  help  develop  performance  criteria,  indicators  of  success,  data  requirements  and 
sources, and data collection frequency; 
(iv)  plan an overall performance measurement and reporting strategy for monitoring the 
progress  of  and  evaluating  the  program  or  policy  initiative,  including  strategies  for 
managing midcourse correction and incorporating lessons learned in future management 
decisions; 
(v)  stipulate the institutional structure and accountabilities for managing for development 
results (MfDR); 
(vi)  with the above in mind, develop an MfDR tool kit for the sector, including the relevant 
forms and formats; and 
(vii)  design and implement a training program and workshops. 
 
9.  The  consultants  should  have  global  experience  in  results-based  management  with 
practical experience working with, and introducing the results-based management approach to, 
practitioners in developing countries. Knowledge of relevant sector development issues would 
be an asset.

Appendix 4  13 
D.  Public–Private Participation Specialist (3 person-months, international) 
10.  The consultant will prepare a work plan for developing outline public–private participation 
(PPP)  frameworks  for  the  selected  sectors,  particularly  education  and  water  supply  and 
sanitation, in the identified Central and West Asian countries. 
 
11.  For each such undertaking, the consultant will  
(i)  review the literature on the current policy and institutional environment and consult with 
the government and private sector stakeholders to identify obstacles to PPP delivery of 
public goods and services, particularly with respect to the following: (a) procurement 
regulations and their compatibility with PPP procurement; (b) depth and maturity of 
financial market for long-term financing of PPP projects; and (c) contract enforcement 
laws and institutional capacity to enforce contractual obligations, including provisions for 
arbitration; 
(ii)  on the basis of the above stocktaking, propose an outline PPP policy and institutional 
framework,  including  the  placement  of  the  PPP  project  development  function,  risk 
sharing and viability assessment function, and any viability gap funding arrangement, 
and identify associated capacities that need to be in place; 
(iii)  develop a process flow for PPP projects from inception to execution;  
(iv)  identify PPP opportunities in social services, particularly in the education and water and 
sanitation, that are consistent with market conditions in the host country, and help 
develop expressions of interest for PPP projects in suitable cases; and 
(v)  design and deliver training workshops in PPP. 
 
12.  The consultant should have extensive knowledge of relevant sector development issues, 
private project finance, and PPPs. Previous exposure to ADB operational work would be an 
advantage. 
E.  Procurement Expert (3 person-months, international) 
13.  The consultant will prepare a work plan for assessing the adequacy of procurement 
frameworks in the identified Central and West Asian countries. 
 
14.  For each such undertaking, the consultant will  
(i)  review the literature on the current procurement policy and institutional environment and 
consult  with  the  government,  consumers  of  public  services,  and  private  sector 
stakeholders to identify obstacles to the economical, efficient, effective, and transparent 
procurement of public goods and services; 
(ii)  analyze  the  legal  and  institutional  framework  with  respect  to  the  provisions  for 
transparency, competition, economy, efficiency, fairness, and accountability, and review 
for conflict-of-interest and dispute resolution provisions; 
(iii)  review  institutional  capacities  and  the  procurement  practices  in  the  context  of 
procurement planning, commitment control, timely payment to suppliers, and existence 
of any offset practices;  
(iv)  on the basis of the above analytical work, identify critical reforms in procurement laws, 
rules, and procedures, and the attendant institutional arrangements; and  
(v)  develop  a  procurement  reform  framework  and  design  innovative  solutions  for 
overcoming any immediate procurement bottlenecks. 
 
15.  The consultant should have extensive experience in procurement practice and advisory 
services. Experience working with national governments in Central and West Asia as well as 
multilateral agencies would be an advantage.

14  Appendix 4 
 
F.  E-governance Experts (3 person-months, international) 
16.  The consultants will prepare a work plan for assessing the appropriateness of and 
introducing e-governance solutions in selected governance areas in the identified Central and 
West Asian countries. 
 
17.  For each such undertaking, the consultants will   
(i)  review  the  legal  and  institutional  environment  and  any  ongoing  public  sector 
e-governance initiatives, and identify their strengths and weaknesses; 
(ii)  consult with government counterparts and public sector service consumers to assess 
opportunities for additional e-governance solutions for government-to-government and 
government-and-citizen  transactions  and  help  develop  criteria  for  prioritizing 
e-governance initiatives, and help define the vision and mission for e-governance and 
the rollout strategy for the identified public service initiative;  
(iii)  develop  the  e-governance  architecture,  and  identify  the  need  for  business  process 
reengineering  and  for  legislative  amendments,  while  also  pointing  out  suitable 
technology options, if appropriate; 
(iv)  develop a human resource development road map for implementing the e-governance 
initiatives; 
(v)  help develop expressions of interest for the identified e-governance initiatives; and 
(vii)  act as resource persons in the training program and workshops. 
 
18.  The consultants will have wide knowledge of and experience in the use of information 
and communication technology in public administration. Experience in preparing strategies and 
broad action plans for implementing e-governance initiatives would be an advantage. 
G.  Training Coordinator (4 person-months, international) 
19.  The consultant will 
(i)  prepare  a  work  plan  for  undertaking  rapid  training  needs  assessments  for  sector 
planning and PFM and procurement, particularly in education and water and sanitation 
sectors in the identified Central and West Asian countries; 
(ii)  review the institutional environment for in-service training including the adequacy of the 
budget, and propose remedial actions; 
(iii)  design and apply tools for rapid training needs assessment in relevant government 
agencies; 
(iv)  develop training options and modules, including training materials; 
(v)  organize training programs and workshops, preferably in collaboration with local public 
and private sector training institutions; 
(vi)  develop protocols for peer-to-peer learning, mentoring, and secondment; 
(vii)  exploit synergies among the Central and West Asian countries and organize a regional 
conference and study and exposure visits; and 
(viii)  coordinate  with  the  team  leader  the  training  program,  workshops,  and  regional 
conference. 
 
20.  The consultant must have international work experience in the design, organization, and 
implementation of learning programs for civil servants and other capacity development activities. 
A good working knowledge of PFM issues would be an asset. 
 
H.  Legal Expert (2 person-months, international) 
21.  The  consultant  will  prepare  a  work  plan  for  reviewing  the  legal  and  institutional 
framework for  sector  planning  and  PFM,  including the  procurement  and  the  anticorruption 
environment, in the identified Central and West Asian countries.

Appendix 4  15 
 
22.  In each such undertaking the consultant will 
(i)  review the legal framework governing the identified area of operation and a capacity 
assessment of the mandated institutions, and consult with government counterparts and 
other key nongovernment stakeholders; 
(ii)  identify weaknesses in regulations or implementation capacity, from the point of view of 
protecting the public interest, and bringing the proposed reforms in the identified areas of 
operation in line with international best practices and norms; 
(iii)  propose improvements in the regulatory institutional regime; and 
(iv)  act as resource persons in the training program and workshops. 
 
23.  The consultant must know well the legal framework in ADB’s Central and West Asia 
developing member countries especially for PFM. Experience with national governments in 
Central and West Asia as well as multilateral agencies would be an advantage.  
I.  National Consultants (14 person-months, national) 
24.  The national consultants will have extensive and in-depth local knowledge of public 
administration and good contacts in government. They will be guided and supervised by the 
respective international consultants, whom they are expected to support by, among other things, 
translating various documents into English; and researching and compiling government policies, 
regulations, and adopted procedures. 
J.  Training Coordinator(s) (4 person-months, national) 
25.  The  consultant(s)  will  assist  the  international  training  coordinator  in  organizing  the 
training program, workshops, and regional conference. Specifically, the consultant(s) will 
(i)  handle administrative and logistical matters (including contracts, travel arrangements, 
and  reimbursements)  with  regard  to  participants,  resource  persons  in  the  training 
programs, workshops, and regional conference; 
(ii)  help organize the training programs, workshops, and regional conference;  
(iii)  help prepare materials for the training programs, workshops, and regional conference; 
(iv)  coordinate with training experts to ensure that activities are implemented according to 
ADB rules and guidelines on various aspects of management and control; and 
(v)  assist the international training coordinator in preparing reports, maintain records of the 
training programs, and prepare and maintain a database of participants. 
 
26.  The consultant(s) will have at least 2 years’ experience in organizing and administering 
training programs, workshops, conferences, and similar events.  
K.  Resource Persons for the Regional Conference 
27.  The resource persons will perform the following functions, among others: 
(i)  help  design  and  deliver  specific  training  and  capacity-building  modules  in  identified 
areas; 
(ii)  facilitate workshops and share international experience and recognized good practices; 
 
28.  The  resource  persons  will  have  a  strong  background  in  public  administration,  and 
extensive experience in public policy and PFM. They must have international work experience in 
the design and delivery of executive programs for civil servants.
